cards.front: What is the impulse response h(t)?
cards.back: The output when input is δ(t). It completely characterizes an LTI system. Once you know h(t), you can find output for any input using convolution.

h(t) = 0 for t < 0

Causal system cannot respond before impulse occurs. No output before input.

∫|h(t)|dt < ∞

Impulse response must be absolutely integrable. Bounded inputs give bounded outputs.
Yes! ∫|e^(-at)|dt = 1/a < ∞. Decaying exponentials are always stable. Faster decay (larger a) is more stable.
No! ∫e^(at)dt = ∞. Growing exponentials are unstable. Output grows without bound for bounded inputs.

h_total = h₁ * h₂

Cascade means convolve impulse responses. Order doesn't matter (convolution is commutative).

h_total = h₁ + h₂

Parallel means add impulse responses. Input goes to both, outputs add.
Identity system (wire). Output equals input: y = x*δ = x. Signal passes through unchanged.
Integrator. y = x*u = ∫x(τ)dτ. The step function integrates all past values of input.
Ideal delay by T. y = x*δ(t-T) = x(t-T). Signal is delayed by T time units unchanged.
